item.title: No Longer ‘Rising,' Africa Pushed to Margin at Davos - VOA News
item.description:
No Longer ‘Rising,' Africa Pushed to Margin at Davos  VOA News

In this Swiss Alps town where the global elite have gathered to debate the world's problems, there seems to be little room on the radar for Africa, a continent of over a billion people where a commodity-fueled growth boom has soured with a vengeance. Sub-Saharan Africa's economies, described a few years ago by consultancy McKinsey as “lions on the move.” likely expanded just 1.6 percent last year according to the World Bank — the slowest rate in two decades and one that lags the continent's galloping population growth. item.title: Kenya's central bank governor calls for regulation of fintech lenders - Reuters
item.description:
Kenya's central bank governor calls for regulation of fintech lenders  Reuters

By Maggie Fick NAIROBI (Reuters) - A boom in lending by financial technology (fintech) firms in Kenya has led to an increase in predatory lending practices, the country's central bank governor said on Tuesday, calling for the sector to be regulated. Kenya built a reputation as a pioneer of financial inclusion through its early adoption of a mobile money system that enables people to transfer cash and make payments on cellphones without a bank account. item.title: Kenya’s 4G Capital plans tokenised bond via cryptocurrencies - Financial Times
item.description:
Kenya’s 4G Capital plans tokenised bond via cryptocurrencies  Financial Times

4G Capital, a Nairobi-based microfinance and training company, is to become the first such financial institution to issue a tokenised bond using cryptocurrencies. The initial issuance aims to reach about $10m and a targeted coupon of 10 per cent to prove the concept, according to Wayne Hennessy-Barrett, 4G’s founder and chief executive. It will be offered next month to the company’s existing institutional and qualified investors, who can pay in either bitcoin or Ether. item.title: World Bank cuts Kenya’s outlook for growth - Financial Times
item.description:
World Bank cuts Kenya’s outlook for growth  Financial Times

The World Bank has downgraded Kenya’s economic outlook and warned of “significant downside risks that could scuttle the projected rebound” as the country endures its worst political crisis in a decade. President Uhuru Kenyatta, who was sworn in last week for a second term, needs to stimulate the private sector, cut spending on government bureaucracy and end months of political uncertainty caused by disputed elections, the bank said in a report.
